Article: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. â The 18th  annual EmTech Conference opened yesterday on the MIT campus. A major focus of this conference was artificial intelligence (AI) and robotics, with attendees hearing about the great strides that AI (and software in general) will change the way that we live and work. While we can certainly see that coming, there are many jobs â even assembly-line jobs â that are still far too complex for machines. Even so, weâre seeing ethical issues that will haunt us.    Ethical issues have arisen not only because of technologies such as AI but from simply having technologies like the internet, mobile phones, and social media. Gideon Lichfield, EiC of MIT Technology Review, opened by talking about ethics of technology. Using a graphic based on tweets that looked into blue and red posts, not just by followers but by content, Lichfield showed just how polarized we are.       A graphic at the EmTech MIT 2018 conference analyzes tweets to show political polarization. Photo by Martin Rowe.       âWe tend to surround ourselves with like-minded people even though we are exposed to others,â he continued. âWe filter out that which doesnât agree. We did not see this coming.â Showing a cover from 2013, Lichfield noted how, at the time, there was a belief that data would save politics. Instead, we have people who seek to discredit data if they donât like what it shows. The cover also contains a quote that has become more valid today: âThe mobile phone, the Net, and spread of information â a deadly combination for dictators.â (I recently visited two former Soviet Bloc countries. People in both spoke of their countries becoming more autocratic.)      In 2013, people believed that big data would save politics. How wrong they were. Source: MIT Technology Review.       Lichfield went on to note how thereâs a belief in Silicon Valley that we just create technology and stay neutral. Thatâs no longer the case. Why? Because you canât predict how people will use technology. He gave an example of how software can change your face in a video or change your voice to the point at which you can pass for someone else. MIT Technology Review editor Will Knight used freely available software to superimpose Ted Cruz’s face onto actor Paul Rudd in a video. âItâs no longer OK to just create technology. We need to regulate tech for a better society.â     AI has the potential to change society, but it has a long way to go, noted MIT professor Josh Tenenbaum, whose team of researchers is looking for way to make machines learn in a way that mimics the way that humans learn.    âWhy do we have all of these AI algorithms but essentially no AI?â he asked. According to Tenenbaum, machines still lack the learning ability and common sense of humans. âAlgorithms are not even close to the intelligence of even a one-year-old.â So far, the machines in use today, especially in factories, were designed to do just one thing â say, welding â that they can do with better accuracy and repeatability than can people, but the robots do only that one thing. Tenenbaum wants to understand why humans can do so much more than machines. âTodayâs AI technologies are driven by pattern recognition and deep learning. Intelligence is so much more.â       MIT professor Josh Tenenbaum explains how cognitive science becomes artificial intelligence. Photo by Martin Rowe.       Tenenbaum and his students are trying to reverse-engineer the ways that people think and solve problems, then apply that to machines. He reports some exciting progress, saying that we have a long way to go even though the math of deep learning was published in the 1960s to 1980s in psychology journals.     Tenenbaum also noted Alan Turingâs famous 1950 paper, which pointed out that children are the only thing we know of that grows into human life intelligence. Turing assumed that a childâs brain is like a blank sheet of paper, but Tenenbaum said that Turing was wrong. For example, Prof. Rebecca Saxe has shown that we are born with the wiring for intelligence and learning. âWe understand people, places, and things, not just patterns and pixels.â Prof. Laura Schulz studies how children learn by thinking. Tenenbaum looks to their research to model how we learn and apply it to machines.    Tenenbaum then showed two videos of young children solving problems that machines canât currently do. In one, a toddler can stack rings in order by size. In another video, an adult tried to put books in a closet while the closet door was closed. Another toddler could figure out that the doors needed to be open and opened them.    Another conference talk given by Veobotâs Clara Vu echoed Tenenbaumâs claim that âhumans are amazing.â Vu explained the process involved when someone applies mascara. Itâs too complicated for todayâs machines. Vu did, however, show how industrial robots can do things that people canât do. She contrasted tasks in an automobile factory, where robots are much better at welding than people but final assembly is still done by people, noting how both GM and Tesla failed to automate final assembly because it involves many tasks and there are many car models with differences.    Vu noted how automating a single process requires a team of engineers working for months or years and that itâs a large investment. If you change anything in the process, you have to reprogram the machines. People are much better at adapting. âRobots canât assemble a cable harness. With manufacturers being pushed to have varied products, we need a new flexible automation.â      Clara Vu of Veobot described how we need perception and actuation to perform a task. Photo by Martin Rowe.       âWhat makes industrial robots so strong also makes them dangerous,â continued Vu. She explained how robots must be kept in cages to keep people safe. Her company is developing algorithms that use sensors to detect the presence of people near the robot. If the person gets too close, the robot ceases operation. âWe built the systems to be fail-safe. We analyze the entire space. If we canât guarantee that a space isnât occupied, we assume that itâs occupied.â While this function doesnât require machine learning, it does show how people can work alongside robots. Vu described this as âold-fashioned AI.â    Vu explained that robotics includes actuation. âRobots have to do something. While actuation is simple, perception is hard. We are still decades or centuries away from machines performing some human actuation. We have to solve many problems before we can make a flexible factory like we can with humans. Robots can make cable harnesses.â    While Tenenbaum and Vu see situations in which robots still canât compete with people, Ganesh Bell, founder of Uptake, claimed that âevery business will be reimagined with software. AI will process data taken by IoT devices. AI and predictive analytics is the next productivity boost.â Bellâs company produces software that can be used for predictive analytics. But he noted that people still have to act on those predictions to prevent unwanted disruptions in machine operations.
